options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture + lab
In-person lectures with four virtual labs and four quizzes (no finals)
combination of virtual lecture and virtual lab
None
We had review sessions through zoom before quizzes that were really helpful! And they accommodated to times when students were most available
The class also had online labs.
In addition to live virtual lectures, lecture recordings were also posted for each lesson. Live virtual review sessions were held as well before tests.
virtual lecture and lab
N/A.
labs, review sessions
virtual lab
The class was also a virtual lab.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of different parts/bones of the human body

I learned a lot about bones! This is an identification-heavy class so there is a lot of memorization involved. It was really interesting for me to point to a part of my body and know what bone (or bone feature) goes there.

During this class, I was able to learn not only the anatomy of the human musculoskeletal system but also how different parts of this system formed. Also, I was able to learn how to identify individuals based on age and sex from just viewing different parts of their skeleton.
I learned every single bone in the body and their attachments/insertions.
I learned about human anatomy and aging and sexing based on specific bones.
Every single bone in the human body!! Professor Sargis is an awesome professor and really teaches his students well so that they understand bones in orientation on their own body.
I learned a great deal about human anatomy, particularly that of bones and their muscular insertions.
I learned a lot about human bones, how to identify, age, and sex them, and about the attaching muscle groups and nerves.

In this course I learned the bones of the human skeleton as well as their various features and functions. I also learned the muscles and ligaments that originate from or insert into each bone, as well as veins and arteries that go through the concavities created by skeletal structure. I also learned how to determine sex and age of specimens based on their bone features, and Professor Sargis provided various practical purposes of the materials that we learned in class.
Every single bone in the body! And their muscle attachments, which is helpful--also how to identify and side bones in an archaeological context.
I learned about the human skeleton and how to identify and side certain bones by looking at key features.
Learned almost every bone and relevant muscle attachments, pretty straightforward

I learned so much about the bones of the body, their features, how to identify them, and how they related to soft tissues or veins. I understand the human body so much better now and found this an incredibly valuable learning experience.
Every bone and quite a few muscle attachments are solidified in memory after the course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Interesting lectures and straightforward grading

I really enjoyed it when Prof. Sargis talked about the practical values of bone features. I could try moving a joint and see exactly how bone structures play a part. I think the only negative was how it was online and not in class (not Sargis' fault).

I think the pace of the class went pretty well. The labs were great because we were given a chance to try and work out the lab on our own before going over them together and since they occurred the class before the quiz, they were a great review. I definitely feel that in-person, labs would be even more engaging,
This course was awesome and they did a great job of formatting it to be virtual. Prof. Sargis provides many resources to succeed. The class uses a great textbook.

Professor Stargis is very passionate about anthropology and it showed during lecture. He is very attentive to students and answers every question they have. The labs were helpful for review before quizzes.

Strengths include the volume of material taught. In the beginning of the semester I never wouldve thought that I would have been able to memorize every bone in the human body in 14 weeks, but the class structure and Professor Sargis make it easy to learn. 

One weakness was that it is hard to not just memorize the photo and what the bone is. Because we were not in lab with different specimens, we were looking at the same photos for the same bone when in reality the same bone looks different on different skeletons.

The professor is very knowledgable on the topic which made for a great learning experience but the online nature of the course, given that it is usually an in-person, specimen-based science lab, there were times when I definitely wished I could learn the material by actually seeing and experiencing the specimens rather than simply memorizing images of them.
I think that this course would have been fantastic had it been in-person, but it's very hard to study bones when you can't see them in real life.

Professor Sargis' teaching style makes this class very engaging and interesting, and I'm sure it would be even more so under normal conditions in which we would have actually gotten to examine bone specimens. A major strength of this class is that the grading policy and assignments are all very clear and simple- 4 labs and 4 tests, and a clear grading scale based on the percent average of these grades. Having a very clear rubric and grading policy was very helpful. I would say one small weakness might be that the content was very memorization heavy. But as long as you're willing to put in the time to memorize all the bone structures this shouldn't pose a problem!
This is a course that would be extremely interesting in person! However, it was challenging to identify bones through images alone.

It's very clear, well-taught, and fascinating! My only constructive feedback is to show us the bones on camera more. We had lots of excellent images, but when professor Sargis picked the bone out of a box and showed it to the camera, I was able to much better understand the shape and structure of the bone (especially for more complex bones). I recommend doing this for more boneswe can turn on speaker view so professor Sargis takes up the majority of the screen, and then he can show us the 3D bone and point out the same features we saw in the 2D images.

For a live virtual lecture, I thought the slides were pretty comprehensive and having them available during prior to was extremely helpful so you could keep track/take notes. Of course, this class would be more engaging if it were in-person but I think the professor adapted pretty well to an online format (the websites/resources and study guides were great for exam prep).
No weaknesses. Amazing lecture by Eric all the time.

Strengths: Clear and to the point, concise
Weaknesses: My own attention span for online lectures is not quite as long as the class not really the course's fault
Given that the course was online, when normally it is a lab, it was a great class and handled perfectly.

A strength would be the content of the lectures and how well-organized the course was!

A weakness would be that I never got to know any of the other students and, of course, that we didn't have the labs in person-- but I'm sure this is just because the class was virtual.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Views of the bone are sometimes difficult virtually, more real images of bones would be helpful

This class is normally taught in the bone lab where we would see real human samples of each bone. Because we were relying on images from the textbook and other sources, it was a lot harder to visualize the bones in 3D space. This isn't really Prof. Sargis' fault, but I do think that I would have been able to grasp the concepts easier in person.
Live lectures with PowerPoint presentation. Interactive questions throughout.
Lecture wasnt always the most engaging or interactive.

The virtual labs were good, but I wish we had more training on strategies to study bones using those labs and how we would go about analyzing the bones in real life. Maybe like in physics lab, we could be each sent little bone kits to study on our own.

The online lectures ran smoothly and the recordings and powerpoints were all posted in Canvas, making the course material easy to find. All tests were administered through Respondus Lockdown Browser to prevent cheating, and this program also ran smoothly for the most part(with a few issues with student's tests freezing up, but I believe all issues were resolved).

It was pretty successful! Clear lectures, and expectations were modified given online learning (i.e., fewer features/bones we needed to know/side). My only feedback is above in q5 (i.e., showing 3D bones on camera).

I'm not sure if the professor knows this, but Yale specifically has a rule that says, "Exams should not use both Respondus Lockdown Browser AND a remote proctor on Zoom for the same assessment. Doing so will present significant technical complications. Instructors must choose between Respondus Lockdown Browser OR a remote proctor on Zoom." Each exam, however, had used both lockdown browser and zoom. I luckily had a phone with a front-facing camera and a laptop so this type of proctoring wasn't a problem, but I do think the professor should be aware of this and how it may impact future students if this course is taught online next semester.  Other than that, the way the course ran went pretty smoothlythe study guides and slides were very helpful for labs and quizzes.

Could maybe find a way to make lectures and labs more interactive? Recording the lectures would've helped me a lot because the explanations were good and I would've appreciated having them available to look back at to review

The lectures and labs were definitely less than ideal but still really good considering the pandemic! I think in the beginning that Professor Sargis mentioned that in past years students would have received a model of the skeleton to take to their dorms... if I'm remembering that correctly, it would have been helpful if on-campus students could still pick those up. 

Also, if we could have access to images of skeletal material from more individuals that would have been really helpful as well. Sometimes the lab or quiz was the first time I'd seen a certain bone outside of the textbook and I realized I had learned what the textbook's bone looked like, but not what that bone actually looked like across individuals.
It worked very well considering COVID limitations.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're interested in learning more about human bones

Yes! As long as you are okay with a lot of memorization, this is a great science course for non-STEM majors. It's interesting and not too intensive. Your final grade is made up of 4 labs (where we go over the answers at the end, so a guaranteed 100%) and 4 quizzes (basically the same as the labs but closed note). I really liked how there was no final (awesome if you're taking other final-intensive classes)

I would definitely recommend this course to students who are looking for a lab, an anatomy course, or a combination of both. I definitely feel like I learned a lot. It is a pretty straightforward class where you are told exactly what you need to learn and when you need to learn it by. The best way to do well in this class is to study regularly and attend the review sessions which are a great way to do an overall review with peers before the quizzes.
Yes this is one of the best courses I have taken. It is so rewarding learning this type of stuff.
I would recommend this class to another student - it was very interesting to learn about the human body.

I would recommend this course to another student - keep in mind that it is VERY memorization heavy, especially online. Make sure to use all of the resources available and try to memorize the features in chunks instead of the night or two before the quiz. Quizzes were pretty straightforward

Yes!! Professor Sargis is awesome. This class however is strictly memorization, but very rewarding when you finish the semester knowing you studied every bone in the human body. I am not a STEM major and I really enjoyed this class, and I didnt feel at a disadvantage not being a STEM major

Yes, definitely, especially if you are pre-med. It helped me learn new ways to memorize large amounts of content and information, which would likely come in handy you're going into the medical field. It was also great to learn about human anatomy, something that is not offered by too many Yale courses.
Take this course if you're ready for lots of memorization and try taking it in-person instead of online.

Yes, I would highly recommend this class to any students interested in orthopedics, radiology or anatomy in general. It provides a very comprehensive learning of the skeletal system as well as associated muscles, ligaments, veins, arteries and nerves. Professor Sargis is an excellent professor and I would readily take another course taught by him. The requirements of the class are very clear and a comprehensive study guide was provided for every test, so there are no surprises when it came to what was on the tests.
Yes! Take this course. Very well taught, helpful in your life (knowing bones makes you look smart and cool!). Also very good if you need a science credit.
Sure! Perhaps take in-person so you get the experience of learning human osteology in person.
Absolutely
Yes if you want to learn about bones
Yes, easy and learned a lot

Yes, absolutely! I love anthropology and archaeology but didn't think of myself as a science student, but I felt like in this course I was learning real science and actually loved it. I think about Osteology now when I'm exercising, in my art, just in life in general. Super helpful and applicable knowledge that was really enjoyable to learn!
Yes, amazing and engaging course.
